questions.text: Sagar was being tried in a  court for the murder of Mohan in the park. Shikhar appeared in court and said he saw Sagar carrying a knife in his hand while in the park. What is this evidence known as?
questions.solution:
This evidence is known as indirect evidence. Indirect evidence is also known as circumstantial evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eyewitness. It has an effect on other facts and subsidiary facts which are depended upon as consistent. 

Other options:

Option A: Direct evidence is the evidence of a fact that is actually in issue. Eg: The witness saw A shooting B, prescription, consent form

Option C: Hostile evidence is given by someone who is supposed to have some interest or motive for hiding part of the truth. He might give completely false evidence too. 

Option D: Hearsay evidence is given by someone about something that he did not personally witness. Sometimes it might be obtained from a third party. It is presented in the court to claim that the facts contained in the statement are true.

questions.text: Fingerprint first develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
Fingerprint first develops in 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life. It is complete by 24 weeks. In identical twins also the pattern is different. 

The image given below shows the different patterns of fingerprints:

Changes might occur in fingerprints in certain conditions, some of them are given below: 

Fingerprint changes

Condition
 Incomplete atrophy of ridges Dermatitis
Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy Celiac disease
Altered ridges Scleroderma
 Permanent loss of fingerprints Radiation
Distance between ridges changed but pattern is retained Acromegaly

questions.text: Identify the given plant.
questions.solution:
The given plant is Argemone mexicana.

The flowers are yellow in color. All parts of the plant are poisonous. Oil extracted from argemone seeds is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil. Sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine are the toxic alkaloids present in the oil and it causes epidemic dropsy. 

Epidemic dropsy is characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Other options:

Option C: Nerium odorum - Flowers are usually white, pink, dark red, or pale yellow in colour. All parts of the plant including nectar, are poisonous. It contains several cardiac glycosides such as neriodorin, neriodorein, and karabin. The action of neriodorin mimics digitalis causing death due to cardiac failure. It can resist heat and hence can be found even in burnt dead bodies. 

 

Option D: Papaver somniferum - The flowers are white in color. Opium is the dry juice of this plant. Morphine is isolated from opium. The clinical features include euphoric feeling in the stage of excitement followed by headache, giddiness, and a tendency to sleep in the stage of stupor. The stage of narcosis is characterized by a patient in a deep coma, who cannot be aroused. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

Related Pearl: Toxic manifestations of Datura

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises upto 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease

questions.text: A male patient was presented with a history of consumption of an unknown substance.  He had increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and bradycardia. What's the management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of organophosphate consumption and atropine is used for its management. Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist and it competitively blocks the acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. 

Organophosphates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. It is absorbed by inhalation or through the skin. Mucous membranes and the gastrointestinal tract are also the sites for absorption. 

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhoea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue and facial muscles along with tachycardia which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headache, tremors, ataxia, coma and death. 

Atropine in larger doses can lead to atropine toxicity. The features are depicted in the following image: 

Other options:

Option B: Calcium gluconate is used as the antidote for oxalic acid poisoning. 

Option C: Pralidoxime is also used in organophosphate poisoning which is used to counter the nicotinic effects of organophosphates. 

Option D: Obidoxime is used in organophosphate poisoning if pralidoxime is not available. 

 

Note: In OP poisoning, the frequency of occurrence is Muscarinic --> CNS --> Nicotinic signs and symptoms. The definitive treatment, however, is atropine.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Organophosphorus Poisoning

Symptoms

Drug used for treatment

Muscarinic symptoms and CNS effects

 Atropine

Nicotinic symptoms

 Pralidoxime

Nicotinic >muscarinic and CNS effects

 Diacetyl monoxime-specific cholinesterase reactivator

Convulsions

 IV diazepam

Pulmonary oedema, bronchospasm

 Oxygen, atropine, intubation, positive pressure ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cocaine intoxication?

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.solution:
Constricted pupils and bradycardia are not a feature of cocaine intoxication. Dilated pupils and rapid pulse are seen in cocaine intoxication.

Cocaine is obtained from the leaves of Erythroxylum coca. Cocaine can be administered by snorting, intravenous route, or smoking.

The manifestations of cocaine intoxication occur in two stages- the stage of excitement and the stage of depression.

In the stage of excitement, the features seen are dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature. There may be a feeling of well-being, and the patient may be excited, restless, and talkative. This progresses into a calm, dull state. Neurological manifestations include exaggerated reflexes, tremors or convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.

The stage of depression is characterized by feeble respiration, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death. 

The fatal dose of cocaine is 1g when taken orally. The fatal period ranges from a few minutes to hours. 

Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin. This is known as cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptom. Ulceration of the nasal septum may be seen in chronic abusers who sniff cocaine. 

Treatment includes gastric lavage with warm water containing potassium permanganate, charcoal, or tannic acid if taken orally. When it is through the nose or throat, a wash with water is done. In case of intravenous intoxication, a ligature is applied above the site of the injection.

The antidote for cocaine intoxication is inhalational amyl nitrite. Other measures include control of convulsions, airway and circulatory stabilization, administration of iv thiamine, and naloxone.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance

Intoxication features

Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech

Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

Related Pearl: Specific effects of substance abuse

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning?

1. Raindrop pigmentation
2. Peripheral neuritis
3. Mees line
4. Luminous vomit
questions.solution:
Among the given options, raindrop pigmentation, peripheral neuritis, and mees line are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning. Luminous vomit is a feature of yellow phosphorous poisoning. 

Arsenic is an odorless, tasteless, metallic poison. Gastrointestinal features of acute arsenic poisoning include nausea and vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and profuse diarrhea with rice water stools.

In chronic arsenic poisoning, skin symptoms include erythematous lesions, flushing, and can also lead to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Pigmentation is patchy and resembles raindrops on a dusty road. In the distal parts of the body, hyperkeratosis is present.  Mees lines are transverse white striae of the fingernails, called striate leukonychia. Renal manifestations include chronic nephritis and urine contains albumin, casts, etc. 

Arsenic can be detected in the bones for prolonged periods. Hence it can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. Dimercaprol is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: Post-mortem examination of a patient reveals the following. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
The finding is known as hesitation cuts. It is a feature of suicide. They are small multiple cuts which involve only the superficial skin. They are seen at the beginning of the incised wound. The throat, wrist and front of the chest are the most common sites. Unintentional cuts are seen on the fingers in which the razor blade are held. 

Other options:
Option B: Grazed abrasion occurs when there is movement between skin and some rough surface. The epidermis is destroyed and shows uneven longitudinal parallel lines in the direction of the force. Cleaning and dressing is the treatment. 

Option C: In laceration tearing of the skin, mucous membrane, muscles or internal organs occurs due to blunt force application. The tissues are crushed and stretched beyond their elasticity limit. 

Option D: In Patterned bruise, it mirrors the pattern of the object used. The tissue is crushed if heavier objects are used and will produce a solid contusion pattern. 

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: Poisoning with which of the following agents would cause hypertension?
questions.solution:
Poisoning with cocaine cause hypertension. This is due to the inhibition of norepinephrine at the adrenergic terminals leading to increased sympathetic stimulation. This effect occurs at all concentrations of cocaine and causes hypertension and ventricular ectopics.

Cocaine is obtained from the plant Erythroxylum coca. The symptoms of cocaine poisoning are divided into two stages:

  1. Stage of excitement: This stage is characterized by features like dysphagia, dryness in the mouth, tachycardia, and dilated pupils. The reflexes are exaggerated and are associated with tingling and numbness in the hands and feet. 
  2. Stage of depression: This stage presents with feeble respiration, profuse sweating, convulsions, and death. In most cases, the cause of death is cardiopulmonary failure or vascular collapse. 

Chronic users develop a feeling of insects crawling through the skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin. This is pathognomic for cocaine poisoning and is known as cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptoms. Ulceration and sometimes perforation of the nasal septum are seen in chronic abusers due to the sniffing habit. 

The image of the nasal septum of a chronic abuser is shown below:

The image of the plant is shown below:

Other options:

Option A: Organophosphorous poisoning produces autonomic instability. Both tachycardia and bradycardia can be seen, however, usually it is the parasympathetic effects which predominate.

Option B: Paracetamol poisoning causes hypotension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, etc. 

Option C: Arsenic poisoning causes vasodilation, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, etc.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is :
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning.

Arsenic is an odorless, tasteless, metallic poison. Gastrointestinal features of acute arsenic poisoning include nausea and vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and profuse diarrhea with rice water stools.

In chronic arsenic poisoning, skin symptoms include erythematous lesions, and flushing and can also lead to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Pigmentation is patchy and resembles raindrops on a dusty road. In the distal parts of the body, hyperkeratosis is present.  Mees lines are transverse white striae of the fingernails, called striate leukonychia. Renal manifestations include chronic nephritis and urine contains albumin, casts, etc. 

Arsenic can be detected in the bones for prolonged periods. Hence it can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body.

Other options:

Option A: Ipecac is an emetic used in ergot and hydrocarbon poisoning.

Option B: Penicillamine is used in lead poisoning as a chelating agent. 

Option C: Activated charcoal acts as an adsorbing agent in many poisonings like aspirin, phenobarbital poisoning, etc. 

 

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

questions.text: To detect vaginal cells on a person who is accused of rape,  which test will you use?
questions.solution:
Lugol's iodine test will be used to detect the vaginal cells present on the penis of a rape accused. It shows brown color on filter paper due to the presence of glycogen in epithelial cells of the vagina. 

Other options:

Option A: Florence test is used to detect choline in that originates from seminal vesicles. It produces dark brown, rhombic, or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide if semen is present. 

Option B: Barberio test is used to detect spermatic fluid. It produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate when picric acid is added to spermatic fluid. 

Option D: Precipitin test is used for species identification of semen stain. A positive test will confirm human origin.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Which of these is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of A. belladonna poisoning: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions, and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis, and urinary retention. 

Other options:

Option A: Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconitum napellus (shown below). Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves and skeletal and smooth muscles. Symptoms include intestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain, and diarrhea), cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), and neurological (vertigo and restlessness) manifestations.

Option B: Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerbera thevetia (shown below). Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Option C: Nicotine is a plant alkaloid derived from the Nicotiana tabacum plant, shown in the image below. It is a cardiac poison.

All components of this plant are poisonous except its ripe seeds. It is a cardiac poison that initially stimulates the autonomic ganglia to produce symptoms of acute intoxication (tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache). These symptoms later subside to give way to respiratory depression and collapse.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

Related Pearl: Certain specific clinical features diagnostic of poisons and poisoning

Clinical features Possible causes
Pupillary constriction (Miosis) Barbiturates, caffeine, carbamates, carbolic acid (phenol), clonidine, methyl dopa, nicotine, opiates, organophosphates, parasympathomimetics.
Pupillary dilatation (Mydriasis) Alcohol (constricted in coma), amphetamines, antihistamines, benzodiazepines, carbon monoxide, cocaine, cyanide, datura (atropine), ephedrine
Hippus (alternate constriction and dilatation of pupils) Aconite, alcohol, barbiturates.
Nystagmus Alcohol, barbiturates, carbamazepine, phencyclidine, phenytoin
Pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate Opioids, cholinesterase inhibitors (organophosphorus or carbamate insecticides), clonidine, phenothiazines, Pontine hemorrhage
Cyanosis Any CNS depressant or agent causing methemoglobinemia
Needle tracks, pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate IV Opioids
Dilated pupils or mid-point pupils, and reduced respiratory rate Benzodiazepines
Dilated pupils, tachycardia
  • Tricyclic antidepressants – dry mouth, warm peripheries, may also be twitchy or have seizures
  • Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine – may also be hallucinating or agitated
  • Anticholinergic drugs such as benzhexol, benztropine – may also have hyperreflexia and myoclonus
  • Antihistamines – may also be drowsy
Increased salivation Organophosphorus or carbamate insecticides

Hypothermia

 

 Lithium, tricyclic antidepressants, anticholinergics, antihistamines

Hyperthermia
  • Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine (also hypertension, tachycardia, agitation, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (also confusion, fluctuating consciousness, rigidity, tremor, autonomic instability, sweating, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Serotonin syndrome (also agitation, clonus, tremor, hyperreflexia, sweating, tachycardia)
  • Salicylates including aspirin (also tachycardia, metabolic acidosis, restlessness, hyperventilation)
Hypertension Amphetamine, ephedrine, cocaine, clonidine, MAO inhibitors, thyroid hormones
Hypotension Cyanide, alcohol, digitalis, carbon monoxide, narcotics, barbiturates
Abdominal cramps, diarrhea, tachycardia, restlessness, hallucinations Withdrawal from: Alcohol, benzodiazepines, opioids
Bradycardia Beta-blockers, calcium antagonists (not dihydropyridines), digoxin, opioids, organophosphorus insecticides, centrally acting alpha agonists, e.g. clonidine
Seizures Tricyclic antidepressants, theophylline, antihistamines, anticonvulsants, non-steroidal drugs, phenol, phenothiazines, isoniazid, cocaine, carbon monoxide, organophosphorus insecticides, strychnine

questions.text: The image given below is a type of _______.
questions.solution:
The type of injury shown in the image is a contusion.

A contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.

  • A pure bruise lies beneath an intact epidermis.
  • Bruises are caused by damage to veins, venules, and small arteries. 
  • The usual bruise from a blunt impact is situated in the subcutaneous tissues, often in the fat layer. (Because of the greater volume of soft subcutaneous tissue in fat people, they tend to bruise more easily than thin ones). 
  • Delayed bruising - It is common knowledge among lay persons, as well as doctors, that a bruise may ‘come out’ - that is, become more prominent with the passage of hours or days. This is partly caused by continued bleeding from the ruptured vessels, but mainly by the percolation of free blood from its origin deeper in the tissues upwards towards the epidermis. 

Other options:

Option B: Abrasion, also known as gravel rash, is the destruction of superficial layers of the epidermis. It is caused by friction against a rough surface or by compression. It is of four types:

  • Scratches
  • Grazes
  • Pressure abrasions
  • Impact abrasions

Option C: Laceration refers to a tear or split of the skin, mucous membranes, muscle, or internal organs. It is due to the application of blunt force to a broad area of the body. They are also called tears or ruptures. The laceration may indicate the cause of the injury and the shape of the blunt weapon. The age of the injury can also be determined.

Option D: A stab wound is formed when force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow or pointed object. The object can be a knife, sword, chisel, scissors, or needle. It is deeper than its length and width on the surface of the skin. The edges are clean-cut and inverted.

 
 

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text:
Match the following:
Tooth Age of eruption
A. Canine 1. 6-7 years
B. Lateral incisor 2. 8-9 years
C. First molar 3. 11-12 years
D. Third molar 4. 17-25 years
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option C: A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4.

The time of emergence of secondary dentition or permanent teeth:

Tooth Emergence
First molar 6-7 years
Central incisors 6-8 years
Lateral incisors 7-9 years
First premolar 9-11 years
Second premolar 10-12 years
Canine 11-12 years
Second molar 12-14 years
Third molar 17-25 years

The time of emergence of primary dentition or temporary teeth:

Tooth Emergence
Mandibular central incisor 6-8 months
Maxillary central incisor 7-9 months
Maxillary lateral incisor 7-9 months
Mandibular lateral incisor 10-12 months
First molar 12-14 months
Canine 17-18 months
Second molar 20-30 months

The deciduous teeth all emerge into the mouth by 2.5-3 years.

Note: 6-13 years is the age of mixed dentition. The first molar emerges at 6-7 years. The second molar emerges at 12 years, and the third molar emerges beyond 18 years of age.

questions.text:
Match the following plant poisons with their active principles.
1. Datura a. Atropine
2. Opium b. Abrin
3. Abrus precatorius c. Thebaine
4. Nux vomica d. Strychnine
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-a,2-c,3-b,4-d.

The active ingredients of Datura include the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. The seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. 

Manifestations of Datura toxicity:

  • Dry hot skin (Temperature rises up to 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
  • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
  • Diplopia
  • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
  • Dysphagia
  • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
  • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

Morphine, codeine, and thebaine are natural opioids derived from poppy Papaver somniferum.

Abrin is a toxalbumin of the plant Abrus precatorius, and it acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby, resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, and miosis. Faintness, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur.

The poison obtained from Strychnos nux-vomica seeds is strychnine. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that acts at the postsynaptic membranes of ventral horn motor neurons. Hence, the blockade of these receptors results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features:

  • Tonic-clonic seizures
  • Opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension)
  • Risus sardonicus

questions.text: The dead body of a child was recovered from a river with froth around his mouth, which reappeared even after wiping it off. Which postmortem finding is not seen in this case?

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.solution:
The above case scenario with frothing is suggestive of antemortem drowning. High concentration of arsenic in the shaft of hair is seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning.

 Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant
Fluid and electrolyte changes

Hypervolemia

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia
Time to death

Lesser (4-5 minutes)

More (8-12 minutes)

questions.text: Spanish windlass is a type of which strangulation method?
questions.solution:
Spanish windlass is an improvised version of garrotting, and it involves tightening an iron collar (Spanish windlass) around the neck and forcing a spike against the neck into the spinal cord.

This was a form of judicial execution once employed in Spain. The rod-like object used to tighten the ligature is called a Spanish windlass; this may be a ruler, stick, or screwdriver. 

Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown over the victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting with a lever. 

The image given below shows garrotting.

Option A: Squeezing to death using sticks is called bansdola. The neck or the chest is squeezed between two sticks, one placed in front, and one behind. The neck may also be squeezed with a single stick in front if the victim is lying down.

Option C: Squeezing the neck with the arm and forearm is called mugging. The image below shows mugging.

 

Option D: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck.

questions.text: A person of eonism  derives pleasure from __________.

choices.text: Kissing  and licking of anus by a sexual partner

questions.solution:
A person of eonism (transvestism) derives pleasure from wearing clothes of the opposite sex. It is usually found in males. His dress, manner, occupational interests, and associations are all designed to increase his feeling of being a woman.

Other options:

Sexual pleasure from

  • Kissing and licking of anus by a sexual partner - Anilingus
  • Sexual interest in nonliving objects that are used to generate sexual excitement.  -Fetichism
  • Seeing a female undressing - Voyeurism or scoptophilia

questions.text: A lady underwent cholecystectomy and now she presents with abdominal pain, one month later. An erect abdomen x-ray was taken, and the image is given below.  The following offense comes under _______.
questions.solution:
The x-ray shows a pair of surgical scissors left behind in the abdomen after surgery. The offense comes under res ipsa loquitur. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed.

"Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. He has to merely state what according to him was the negligent act.

This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

Other options:

Option A: Novus actus interveniens: A person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury.

Option C: Res judicata (Section 337, BNSS) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 

Option D: The principle of respondeat superior is used to explain vicarious liability, which explains that the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope.

questions.text: Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to?
questions.solution:
Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing

When the distance between the firing and the victim is between 30-50 cm (in the case of pistols and revolvers), it is a near-shot wound. The victim is within the range of powder deposition, so there is some amount of tattooing present. But it is outside the range of flame, so there will not be any burning or singeing. There will not be any blackening, as it is outside the range of smoke as well.

The injuries related to firearms are:

  • Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing. It is seen in contact shot wounds or distances up to 5-8 cm. Singeing of hair is caused due to burns
  • Blackening - occurs due to the deposit of smoke. It can be removed with a wet cloth. This can be seen up to around 15 cm of firing
  • Tattooing - occurs due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • Greasing and collaring - occur due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues, during its penetration. It can be found in contact, near-shot, or distant shot wounds. 

In a firm contact shot, the imprint of the muzzle of the gun is seen on the skin around the wound. The victim is within the range of flame, hence singeing of the hair will be present. Tattooing begins only when the muzzle-to-target distance is >1cm, like in a loose contact shot.

When the distance between the victim and the firing is 5-8cm, it is called a close shot. The victim is within the range of the flame, hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition will be seen. Singeing, burning, blackening and tattooing will be present.

When the distance between the victim and the firing is >50 cm, it is a distant shot. The victim lies outside the range of flame and powder deposition. Hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition are absent. Burning, blackening, and tattooing are absent.

Related Pearl: Summary of Wound of entry for Rifled Firearm at different Ranges

Characteristics

Contact shot

Close shot

Near shot

Distant shot

Range

In-touch with skin

2.5-7.5 cm

30-60 cm

>60 cm

Size

Largest size

Bullet size

Smaller

Smallest

Shape

Stellate

Circular

Circular

Circular

Muzzle end imprint

Positive

Negative

Negative

Negative

Edge eversion

Positive

Negative

Negative

Negative

Blackening

Negative

Positive

Negative

Negative

Tattooing

Negative

Positive

Positive

Negative

Singeing

Positive

Positive

Negative

Negative

Abrasion collar

Negative

Positive

Positive

Positive

Grease collar

Negative

Positive

Positive

Positive

Contact shot:

This is a contact gunshot entrance wound. Since the barrel contacts the skin, the gases released by the fired round go into the subcutaneous tissue and cause the star-shaped laceration. Note also the grey-black discoloration from the soot, as well as the faint abrasion ring.

Close shot:

  • The wound has been washed and there is stippling. This indicates a close-range gunshot wound because both stippling and fouling are present.

Distant shot:

  • Distant range entrance gunshot wound with eccentric abrasion rim.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of cold water drowning.
questions.solution:
In cold water drowning or immersion syndrome or hydrocution, death occurs due to vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest.

Hydrocution/ immersion syndrome refers to sudden death, following immersion in cold water. Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e. cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve.

Vagus stimulation occurs due to the following mechanisms:

  • Sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx
  • Falling or diving into the water in a manner, so that it suddenly strikes the abdomen, especially the epigastric region
  • Sudden in-rush of cold water into the ears

Types of drowning:

  • Wet drowning/ typical drowning
  • Atypical drowning/dry drowning
    • Immersion syndrome/ hydrocution
    • Post-immersion syndrome/ secondary drowning/ near-drowning 
    • Submersion of the unconscious/ shallow-water drowning

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant
Fluid and electrolyte changes

Hypervolemia

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia
Time to death

Lesser (4-5 minutes)

More (8-12 minutes)

 

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an abrasion due to ligature mark, which is a pressure abrasion.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to injury to the epidermis. They are usually caused by friction against a rough surface or by compression. 

Types of abrasions:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): Caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Examples: nail, thorn, the point of sword or knife
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): Caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin
    • brush burns- tangential rubbing over the surface, usually the ground 
    • friction burns are extensive excoriated areas without bleeding
    • Examples: fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement; usually show the pattern of the object causing them
    • Examples: tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Pressure abrasions (pressure abrasion): Caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis
    • Examples: ligature marks around the neck in hanging

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: Gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Gas shadow in the great vessels of a fetus in intrauterine death is called the Roberts sign. It is the earliest sign and is seen within 12 hours of death. The gas shadow may be present within the chambers of the heart or in large vessels of the fetus.

Signs of intrauterine death:

  • Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
  • Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
  • Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours 
  • Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
  • Spalding's sign (Option B) radiographic finding is seen as a loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of the cranial vault. This occurs due to shrinkage of the brain after death. It is seen 7 days after fetal death.
  • A sweetish and disagreeable odor
  • Sodden and coppery red/purplish skin (never greenish as with putrefaction) with blisters, and cuticle peeling. The skin detaches easily and leaves moist and greasy areas
  • Distended abdomen and thick, red, and soft umbilical cord
  • Abnormally mobile or flexible joints
  • Soft, edematous, and loss of morphology of the organs or viscera (lungs and uterus remain unaffected for long period)
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface

Option C: Ball sign is hyperflexion of the spine with crowding of ribs seen in intrauterine death.

Option D: Halo sign is a radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death showing an increase in soft tissue width between subcutaneous fat and the cranial vault. 

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department with a history of assault by a mob using heavy blunt objects and sharp objects. On examination, crushing of the hair bulb was seen. Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
The type of wound in which the crushing of the hair bulb is seen is a lacerated wound.

Cut lacerations may be produced by blunt weapons or heavy relatively sharp-edged weapons such as axe, hatchets, and choppers. Scalp lacerations can be found in association with bruising and abrasions. Fascial strands, hair bulbs, nerves, and vessels, that run in the depth of the wound, are irregularly torn and crushed.

Margins are irregular, ragged, and uneven. The ends are pointed or blunt. The edges of lacerations, especially over the skull are undermined. The depth of the wound varies according to the thickness of the soft parts at the site of the injury and the degree of force applied.

Medicolegal importance of laceration:

  • The type of laceration indicates the cause of the injury and the shape of the weapon.
  • Foreign bodies found in the wound may indicate the circumstances in which the crime was committed.
  • The age of the injury can be determined.
The image below shows a lacerated wound.

Other options

Option A: An incised wound is clean-cut, regular, and well-defined. Bruising does not occur when caused by light-cutting weapons but bruising and some irregularity of the margins may be present when heavy and not-so-sharp-edged weapons like a shovel, Kassi, axe, tangi, etc. have been used.

Option C: Chop wounds are caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, or hatchet. The margins of the wound depending on the condition of the weapon, a sharp margin with slight bruising is seen with a sharp-edged weapon, and a ragged and bruised margin is seen with a blunt edge. Undermining occurs in the direction towards which the chop is made.

Option D: Avulsion or shearing laceration is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues. It is due to shearing force delivered at an acute angle. Commonly seen in road traffic accidents.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change given in the image.
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown above is marbling, which is an external sign of putrefaction.

In marbling, the superficial veins of roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, and shoulders are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red, in a linear branching pattern. It is usually prominent 36–48 hours after death occurs due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin subsequent to hemolysis of red blood cells.

In putrefaction, bacteria from the gut enter into and multiply in the surrounding tissues, eventually spreading through the blood vessels to other parts of the body. The bacterium Clostridium welchii is largely responsible for the putrefactive changes spreading through the body, due to its production of the enzyme lecithinase. The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying outside in the air is a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the cecum.

Other options:

Option B: Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing

Option C: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to the stagnation of blood in the vessels of the dependent parts due to the effect of gravity. 

Option D: Filigree burns also known as Lichtenberg's flowers are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

questions.text: A male patient working in the matchbox industry for the past 20 years reports to the dentist with multiple sinuses and fistulae in and around his jaw with foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following chemicals are responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a phossy jaw, which occurs due to chronic phosphorus poisoning. Phossy jaw refers to osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses.

Frequent inhalation of phosphorus fumes causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth. Patients initially present with toothache, followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of the bone in the mandible producing considerable facial disfigurement. 

Chronic phosphorus poisoning is common among the workers of phosphorus industries (matchbox factories), who have had chronic exposure to phosphorus fumes for months to years. It is managed surgically and by prevention of further exposure to the poison. 

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms, white phosphorus, a highly toxic form, and red phosphorus, the non-toxic form. 

Fulminant poisoning is seen when more than one gram is consumed, and death occurs within 12 hours due to peripheral vascular collapse. In acute poisoning, they present with pain in the throat and abdomen, with intense thirst, nausea, diarrhea, and severe abdominal pain. System toxicity occurs after 2–3 days and results in hematemesis, enlarged tender liver, jaundice, pruritus, and hemorrhages. The gastric and intestinal content have garlic odor and are luminous.

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb the poison. 

Other options:

Option A: Bromine is a corrosive substance that causes necrosis of skin and tissues.

Option B: The symptoms of antimony poisoning, both acute and chronic are similar to that of arsenic. Inhalation of fumes causes a flu-like illness called metal fume fever. In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should be taken for sampling. 

Option C: Prolonged ingestion of fluorides results in the mottling of teeth, an increase in the density of bones, lipping of bony margins of vertebrae, which sometimes produce pressure on the spinal cord leading to paraplegia.

Related Pearl: Phosphorus poisoning

Features

Phosphorus
Chemistry

2 forms - White and Red Phosphorus

White Phosphorus is toxic, Red Phosphorus is not.
Mechanism of action Protoplasmic irritant poison
Organs affected

Liver

Bone

Kidneys
Characteristic clinical findings

Smoky stool syndrome

Luminescent stools

Garlicky odor

Liver necrosis

Phossy jaw
Treatment

Symptomatic therapy

questions.text:
Which of the following rules of law are associated with insanity?
  1. Durham's rule
  2. Curren's rule
  3. Ashley's rule
  4. Murphy's rule
questions.solution:
Durham's rule and Curren's rule are laws associated with insanity.

Durhams's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Curren’s rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

In India, the law of Criminal responsibility is under BNS Section 22 (Section 84 IPC) It states that "Nothing is an offense which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to the law”. This is slightly different from McNaghten's rule followed in Britain.

M'Naghten's rule states that every man is to be presumed to be sane, and possesses a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes until the contrary is proved.

Other rules to assess the criminal responsibility of insane persons:

  • The Irresistible Impulse
  • Federal rule or American Law Institute test (ALT)
  • The Brawner rule

Note: Ashley's rule is used to differentiate males and females based on the combined length of the manubrium and sternum. It is considered to be a male sternum when the combined length is >149 mm, while if the combined length is <149 mm, then it is considered female. 

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text:
The steps in the management of snake bite include:
  1. Loose tourniquet
  2. Debride to avoid the spread
  3. Kill the snake
  4. Hospitalize for anti-venom administration 
  5. Immobilization
questions.solution:
The management of snakebites includes immobilization and administration of anti-snake venom (ASV) after hospitalization.

Immobilization is done to minimize the spread of the venom. Hospitalization, followed by ASV administration is the definitive management of snake bites.

Measures that can be taken in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. A pressure of 50 to 70 mm Hg is maintained.
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting.

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb 
  • Do not attempt to kill or catch the snake as it may be dangerous.
  • Administration of ASV locally at the wound site.
  • Herbal/local remedies

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to:
questions.solution:
Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of cheap illicit liquor containing methanol, particularly by the lower socio-economic classes.

The central organ for metabolism is the liver. Methanol or methyl alcohol is first oxidized to formaldehyde with the help of alcohol dehydrogenase. It is further metabolized to formic acid via aldehyde dehydrogenase. These metabolites are responsible for the adverse effects of intoxication.

Features seen are ophthalmological complications such as blindness, and optic neuropathy. Brain edema, acute renal failure, and severe metabolic derangement are also seen.
